awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Molar topographic shape as a system for inferring paleoecology and developmental patterning in cercopithecoid evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Primates use their molar teeth to break down food as a first step to its digestion and the acquisition of its nutrients. As might be expected, molar shapes are observed to be tightly linked to the types of foods a species consumes. Additionally, it has been found that the shapes of molar teeth are produced in embryo by an elegant patterning mechanism whereby first molar development has a cascade effect over later-developing teeth. Because teeth are durable and dominate most fossil assemblages, molars are an excellent model system by which to elucidate the biology of extinct animals. This project, conducted by doctoral student Julia Winchester (SUNY Stony Brook University) under the guidance of Dr. Frederick Grine, examines molar shape in living and extinct old world monkeys in order to better understand their evolutionary dietary adaptations, and the embryological developmental patterning of these species. 

Old world monkeys exhibit what is referred to as a bilophodont form of molar cusp organization, and questions persist regarding the type of dietary items that might provided the selective  force for the evolution of bilophodonty. Is it an adaptation to diets that consisted largely of leaves or durable nuts, seeds, and/or fruits? In addition, very little is known regarding early dental development, even of living old world monkeys. This research will use technologies such as X-ray microtomography to create virtual models of molars of living and fossil primates, and cutting-edge analytical techniques from computer science will quantify whole tooth molar shape. For living species with known diets, comparative datasets will be built and used to infer dietary evolutionary transitions in extinct species. Relative shape and form across intra-individual molar teeth in species will be compared with experimental studies of rodents in order to make the first conclusions regarding dental developmental patterning in monkeys. Through these methods, the use of molar teeth as a key to unlock questions regarding dietary adaptations and embryological development in living and fossil primates will be developed, supporting understanding of the ways in which embryological dental development may be related to adaptive function, and how evolutionary adaptation is constrained by available developmental mechanisms.

In its broader impacts, this project will (1) broaden participation of under-represented groups by training a graduate woman in science, (2) enhance the infrastructure for research via free software development and participation in open, online-accessible databases of dental shape data, and (3) support scientific dissemination through public outreach to enhance scientific understanding.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Living primates spend a considerable portion of their lives consuming food, and there is little doubt that diet has played a strong selective role on evolutionary processes across time. Because teeth represent the first part of the digestive system to act on food, there are strong links between tooth shape and diet. Documenting these links allows better understanding of ecologies for living species and evolutionary transitions for fossil taxa. Digital surface scans of primate teeth provide a new analytical domain from which to more comprehensively quantify shape. These shape quantification techniques can also be used to address recent hypotheses positing fundamental principles guiding the development of tooth form across mammals, because evidence for these hypotheses should be observable in tooth shape variation. The doctoral dissertation project supported by this award entailed two primary goals: 1) the development of software, algorithms, and datasets for quantitative shape analysis of digital 3D surface scans representing bones and teeth; and 2) the application of these tools to address questions concerning relationships between dental form and both dietary preferences and inferred embryological developmental processes in extant Old World monkeys. Perhaps the most significant single outcome of this project was the successfully defended doctoral dissertation of the co-PI, but numerous specific outcomes arising from or related to this dissertation can be enumerated.

            The dissertation project achieved several outcomes relating to the development of software, algorithms, and datasets. A free open-source software application for analyzing 3D surfaces in Windows or OSX, titled MorphoTester, was developed and is now available for download (http://morphotester.apotropa.com). This software implements multiple shape analysis algorithms that have previously been applied in the literature using combinations of expensive proprietary software. As a result, the free and open source nature of this software increases access to tools and methods for scientific analysis. The algorithms implemented by this software process surface files using a single 3D data format where previous implementations have been forced to use multiple possibly incompatible formats. This provides a more uniform method for comprehensively describing surface shape quantitatively. This software has been published in the peer-reviewed journal PLoS ONE and has generated citations by subsequent peer-reviewed publications, indicating the demand for this technology for morphological analysis.

To generate data from which to analyze surface shape, this project also supported the collection and 3D scanning of a large dataset of extremely accurate replicas of mandibular teeth belonging to over 600 Old World monkey specimens. Data collection was carried out with museums in the US and abroad, and the co-PI was involved in educational outreach among school-aged children visiting museums as part of this process.  Because the process of 3D scanning involves significant effort and monetary cost, a stated goal of the project was to increase access to scientific data through making 3D scans available to researchers and the public. This dataset is currently being prepared to be shared publically through the MorphoSource online repository (http://www.morphosource.org), which will achieve this goal.

The dataset of mandibular molar teeth belonging to extant Old World monkeys was used to address questions concerning molar form-function relationships and evolutionary/developmental dynamics in an effort that involved contributions from and mentorship of undergraduate research assistants. To consider the first question, dietary preferences for a broad sample of Old World monkey species were gathered from the literature. Surface shape was then quantitatively analyzed for mandibular second molars of individual specimens belonging to these species, and tooth shape was compared against dietary preference. Results indicate that, as expected, tooth form correlates to dietary preferences in Old World monkeys in generally expected ways. Gelada baboons exhibit a tough grass feeding diet and qualitative molar morphology unusual among Old world monkeys, and this species similarly evinces quantitative molar shape unlike that of any other monkeys considered. Quantitative molar shape of Gelada baboons is more similar to bamboo feeding lemurs than to Old World monkeys, despite large differences in molar form between these species. This suggests that these methods may represent a way of assessing functionally-related abstract shape similarities between seemingly dissimilar tooth shapes. From these analyses, predictive models were constructed for later inference of diets for fossil taxa. Analyses of variably worn teeth using these methods also suggest a possible balance between various shape aspects that helps to maintain tooth functionality across wear, providing some evidence for the hypothesis that primate teeth may have evolved to keep themselves functional across the lifespan of an individual. Results of analyses of development-linked shape variation across mandibular molar tooth rows show that later-developing teeth and tooth cusps are more variable in shape and position relatively, supporting predictions from empirical studies of mouse molar development. This is consistent with the hypothesis that there are fundamental and elegant developmental principles that, with minor modifications, have guided the evolution and development of a vast diversity of mammalian tooth shape. 

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2016
Modified by: Julia Winchester
